dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Barack Obama just praised the Job Creators of America for releasing their donor lists.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Barack Obama just praised the Job Creators of America for releasing their donor lists.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans for Job Security had previously claimed it was not a political organization and therefore did not have to disclose its donors. But after years of litigation, CREW convinced the Federal Election Commission otherwise.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's huge, because they were always so secretive before, right? Insisting they were purely philanthropic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's huge, because they were always so secretive before, right? Insisting they were purely philanthropic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans for Job Security had previously claimed it was not a political organization and therefore did not have to disclose its donors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the list covers 2015 to 2017—and the numbers are staggering. George Soros alone donated over $100 million through his foundations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the list covers twenty fifteen to twenty seventeen-and the numbers are staggering. George Soros alone donated over one hundred dollars million through his foundations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: AJS filed a list of its backers and beneficiaries from 2010 to 2012 on Thursday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that is… a lot of money. And then you've got the Walton Family, Walmart's founders, with another $75 million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that is... a lot of money. And then you've got the Walton Family, Walmart's founders, with another seventy five dollars million.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The biggest individual donor to the group appears to be Charles Schwab, the brokerage titan worth an estimated $7.8 billion. Over the span of three months in 2012, he donated nearly $9 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, which is interesting because they're not usually associated with progressive causes, but here they are.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, which is interesting because they're not usually associated with progressive causes, but here they are.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then Mark Zuckerberg gave $50 million, Jeff Bezos $25 million… it's like a who's who of big tech money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then Mark Zuckerberg gave fifty dollars million, Jeff Bezos twenty five dollars million... it's like a who's who of big tech money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The late Republican megadonors Richard and Helen DeVos gave $1 million to the group in October 2012. Texas oil-and-gas billionaires Richard Kinder, Dan Wilks, Farris Wilks and late Houston Texans owner Robert McNair were also among the donors that year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But what's really striking is who's not on there—no conservative donors at all. No Koch brothers, no major Republican-aligned corporations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But what's really striking is who's not on there-no conservative donors at all. No Koch brothers, no major Republican-aligned corporations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The late Republican megadonors Richard and Helen DeVos gave $1 million to the group in October 2012. Texas oil-and-gas billionaires Richard Kinder, Dan Wilks, Farris Wilks and late Houston Texans owner Robert McNair were also among the donors that year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And then there's this twist—the JCA president, Stephen Colbert, said the list was basically put together from social media rumors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And then there's this twist-the J C A president, Stephen Colbert, said the list was basically put together from social media rumors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a letter to the FEC, AJS president Stephen DeMaura said the list was pulled from bank records, spreadsheets and other records, noting that it probably included some duplicates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, so it might not even be accurate? That's wild. After all that fanfare about transparency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so it might not even be accurate? That's wild. After all that fanfare about transparency.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, Obama called it a turning point, but if the data's shaky, what does that say?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, Obama called it a turning point, but if the data's shaky, what does that say?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is the first time in the Citizens United-era that a dark money group was forced to disclose their donors in a certain time period, said Jordan Libowitz, a spokesperson for nonprofit watchdog group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, referring to the 2010 Supreme Court case that wiped away previous restrictions on political spending.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It definitely raises questions. I mean, you've got names like Warren Buffett and George Lucas on there, but also Chick-fil-A? They donated $50,000?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It definitely raises questions. I mean, you've got names like Warren Buffett and George Lucas on there, but also Chick-fil-A? They donated fifty thousand dollars?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wynn Resorts contributed $500,000 and Bass Pro Shops contributed $50,000 in 2012. (Morris himself contributed another $50,000, according to the filing.)

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kinda ironic given their reputation. But if the list is unverified, maybe none of it's real.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kinda ironic given their reputation. But if the list is unverified, maybe none of it's real.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So was this whole transparency push just… theater?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So was this whole transparency push just... theater?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It sure seems messy. Either way, it's got people talking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It sure seems messy. Either way, it's got people talking.

artist_script:
A quiet evening in Washington, D.C., as political world reacts to a major disclosure.
HostA: Barack Obama just praised the Job Creators of America for releasing their donor lists.
HostB: Yeah, and that’s huge, because they were always so secretive before, right? Insisting they were purely philanthropic.
HostA: Exactly. And the list covers 2015 to 2017—and the numbers are staggering. George Soros alone donated over $100 million through his foundations.
HostB: Wow, that is… a lot of money. And then you’ve got the Walton Family, Walmart’s founders, with another $75 million.
HostA: Right, which is interesting because they’re not usually associated with progressive causes, but here they are.
HostB: And then Mark Zuckerberg gave $50 million, Jeff Bezos $25 million… it’s like a who’s who of big tech money.
HostA: But what’s really striking is who’s not on there—no conservative donors at all. No Koch brothers, no major Republican-aligned corporations.
HostB: Uh-huh. And then there’s this twist—the JCA president, Stephen Colbert, said the list was basically put together from social media rumors.
HostA: Wait, so it might not even be accurate? That’s wild. After all that fanfare about transparency.
HostB: Yeah, like, Obama called it a turning point, but if the data’s shaky, what does that say?
HostA: It definitely raises questions. I mean, you’ve got names like Warren Buffett and George Lucas on there, but also Chick-fil-A? They donated $50,000?
HostB: Which is kinda ironic given their reputation. But if the list is unverified, maybe none of it’s real.
HostA: So was this whole transparency push just… theater?
HostB: It sure seems messy. Either way, it’s got people talking.
